title: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
description: This course covers the foundation knowledge of biochemistry and molecular biology through studying biochemical and cellular processes of the human body. Emphasis will be placed on the metabolic pathways and their interrelationship. Gene regulation and expression, human genetic diseases, and recent biomedical advancements will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: comment on the roles of biomolecules in the human body through their participation in different metabolic pathways; describe the metabolic pathways of carbohydrate, protein, lipid, and nucleic acids in detail, and discuss the ways that the metabolisms are connected; illustrate the mechanisms of gene regulations in prokaryotes and eukaryotes; discuss the impact of mutations in generating different genetic diseases including those associated with metabolic disorders; through topical studies and preparing a presentation, discuss how modern medicine revolutionizes our understanding of metabolism, diseases, and their impact on our daily lives.
syllabus: • Glycolysis, gluconeogenesis and pentose phosphate pathway • Tricarboxylic acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation • Amino acids metabolism • Lipids and lipid metabolism • Integrative metabolism and vitamins • Nucleotide metabolism • Gene regulation in prokaryotes • Gene regulation in eukaryotes • Human diseases I and II • Project Presentation

title: Anatomy and Physiology I
description: This course provides a system-based review of the structures and functions, normal as well as abnormal, of basic tissues, blood and immune system, musculoskeletal system, cardiovascular system, respiratory system and gastrointestinal system. Emphases will be placed on those structures and functions that are relevant to common drug actions, and those that are affected by common drugs.
outcome: After completion of the course, students should be able to: a) explain the functions of the cells and basic tissues; b) describe the basic anatomical features of the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, autonomic nervous, immune, respiratory and digestive systems; c) recall the basic physiological functions of the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, autonomic nervous, immune, respiratory and digestive system; and d) apply their anatomical and physiological knowledge to explain the abnormal conditions of diseases found in these body systems.

description: This course provides students with an introduction to microbiology and infectious diseases. Attention is focused on fundamental aspects of bacterial, fungal, and viral pathogenesis, therapy, control and prevention of infectious diseases. It also includes the basics of hospital infection and control in preventing spread of infection and protecting oneself from infection in the workplace.

Discuss the role of pharmacists in management of infectious diseases and utilization of antimicrobial agents 4. To understand the basis of hospital infection and control, in preventing spread of infection and protecting oneself from infection at workplace.

Factors which influence ADME such as physical/chemical properties of drugs, route of drug administration, pathophysiology, organ function, life style and genetic variation will also be discussed. syllabus: Molecular, Cellular and Physiological bases Pharmacokinetics Modeling and applications

description: This course provides an overview of the latest advancements in pharmaceutical biotechnology with an emphasis on therapeutics and diagnostics involving macromolecules, mainly DNA and protein. outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: illustrate the basic principles of oligonucleotides and proteins as therapeutics, including their research, production, stability, administration, and functions; comment on the principles of immunology in pharmaceutical science and the use of antibodies for the diagnosis and treatment of diseases; use simple bioinformatics tools to conduct basic analysis; illustrate the principles of pharmacogenomics, apply pharmacogenomics tools to set and adjust dosage regimens, and to render decisions on applications of drug products.
syllabus: (1) Protein therapeutics (antibodies, hormones, and other proteins)  (2) Protein diagnosis  (3) Nucleic acid therapeutics (DNA and RNA as drugs)  (4) Pharmacogenomics (prevention of adverse drug reactions and dose optimization)

description: This elective course offers students the opportunity to learn about pharmacy practice in overseas countries. Students participating in the course will gain a better understanding of the daily activities of a pharmacist at the host institution, differences between Hong Kong and overseas health care system and what it is like to be a pharmacist in another country.

title: Community Pharmacy Summer Clerkship
description: This course is intended for students who choose research as an area of concentration in the final year. It consists of one week of clerkship training completed in the summer term before the final year under the supervision of a community pharmacist. Students will gain knowledge and experience in the operational aspects of the pharmacy and participate in the professional services.

title: Hospital Pharmacy Summer Clerkship
description: This course is an elective clerkship consisting of one week clinical pharmacy clerkship training in the hospital setting. It is intended for students who choose research as an area of concentration in the final year. This clerkship provides an overview of the role and function of pharmacist in the hospital pharmacy practice setting. During the clerkship experience, students will participate in activities include ward rounding, communication with other healthcare professionals, provision of drug information to patients and other healthcare providers, participation in the choice, dosing and monitoring of drugs for individual patients to optimize efficacy, safety and cost-effectiveness.

title: Clinical Assessment and Monitoring
description: PHAR 3812 is the preparatory course prior to the clinical clerkship or the pharmacy students at the Prince of Wales Hospital. It allows pharmacy students to experience patient-focused pharmacy practice. The emphasis of this clerkship is to provide quality training to clerkship students in the internal medicine ward and to have more hand-on experience outside the typical classroom. Due to the nature of the clinical pharmacy clerkship, the preparatory course is designed to prepare students for the upcoming clinical pharmacy clerkship, as well as the final year Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE). The main targeted areas in PHAR 3812 include literature evaluation, drug information, clinical assessment & monitoring, patient data documentation, medical chart review, and role play of clinical scenarios.
outcome: • Write coherently and concisely and speak comprehensibly at the outset of the clerkship; • Read basic chart notes from a variety of healthcare providers and have a basic knowledge of the common disease states encountered in the acute care settings; • Be able to critique a medical journal; • Understand the basic concepts of fluid and nutrition; • Be able to accurately obtain medication-related information from a MAR; • Be able to present a comprehensive patient case (e.g., chief complaint, history of present illness, medical, social, and medication history, diagnostic/lab test results, physical findings, assessment and plan); • Be able to identify and appropriately utilise drug information resources to assist with patient-specific drug therapy monitoring; • Be able to retrieve accurate laboratory test results and vital signs for any given patient; • Be able to identify the contents of each portion of the medical record; • Be organised and have developed a system for recording/memorising patient-specific information (e.g., height, weight, allergies, diagnoses, medications, lab values, and subjective complaints);• Have a brief experience on how the OSCE is conducted.
syllabus: 1. Medical chart documentation 2. Professional communication skills 3. Literature evaluation 4. Basic concepts of fluid and nutrition 5. Drug information techniques 6.  Mock OSCE experience

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Cardiology
description: The clinical clerkship is a minimum of 3-week clerkship for the pharmacy students at the Prince of Wales Hospital. It allows pharmacy students to experience patient-focused pharmacy practice. The emphasis of this clerkship is to provide quality training to clerkship students in the cardiology ward. This will allow students to have more hand-on experience outside the typical classroom. Activities of the clerkship include daily pharmacy rounding, communication with other healthcare professionals, participation in the choice, dosing, and monitoring of drugs for individual patients to optimise efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness during daily case discussion with preceptor and the hospital pharmacy rotation. This is a higher level of training that requires higher expectations and levels of responsibility. As a student pharmacist in the clinical clerkship, you are expected to be hardworking and dedicated. You will be dealing with patient lives and some of the most prestigious cardiologists in Hong Kong.

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Infectious Diseases
description: This course is an elective clerkship at the hospital. The focus is on the purulent use of antimicrobial therapy according to institutional guidelines. The course also emphasizes the clinical techniques to apply pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of antimicrobials in patient care. The up-to-date treatment guidelines of infectious diseases will be discussed.
outcome: • Design of the empirical antimicrobial regimen • Dosage adjustment of antimicrobial • Switch route of administration (e.g. IV to PO switch)  • Antimicrobial streamlining • Therapeutic drug monitoring for antimicrobial therapy
syllabus: • Antimicrobial stewardship program • Community versus healthcare-associated infections • Spectrum of antimicrobial agents • Renal dosage adjustment for antimicrobial agents • De-escalation of antimicrobial therapy
required_readings: N/A
recommended_readings: • Guidelines published by Infectious Diseases Society of America • Hospital Authority IMPACT guidelines.

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Psychiatry
description: This elective clerkship provides students with exposure to patient care and pharmacy practice in psychiatry. The clerkship learning activities include ward rounding, patient interviewing, communicating with other health-care professionals, reviewing of psychiatric regimen and providing drug information to patients and other health-care providers.
outcome: • Be able to demonstrate an understanding on clinical manifestation and usual care for common psychiatric illnesses; • Be able to appreciate the essential components of a mental status examination and selection of drug therapy from psychiatrist’s perspective; • Be able to identify any drug-related issues after reviewing the regimen of patients with consideration on efficacy, adverse effects, drug-drug interactions, laboratory data, cost and local drug use policies; • Be able to develop a working relationship and communicate effectively with the health-care team, including psychiatrists, nurses, social workers, etc.
syllabus: • Introduction to Psychiatric Pharmacy Clerkship • Anxiety disorder • Depression  • Schizophrenia • Bipolar disorder • Patient Interviewing and Counselling

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Oncology
description: This course is an elective clerkship providing an introduction to the pharmacological management of various hematological malignanies, namely leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, and autologous stem cell transplant. Students will participate in ward rounds with hematology oncologists, as well as shadow in the hematology outpatient clinic. Students will learn about disease pathology, symptomology, diagnostic parameters, and drug monitoring parameters through patient case discussion. Other topics including oncology supportive care, antimicrobial prophylaxis, and pain control will also be covered.
outcome: • Describe the common treatment options for the various hematologic malignancies • Understand the rationale of the use for the different supportive care medications • Familiarize with the common adverse side effects of the drugs used in this specialty  • Analyze a patient case and identify any drug-related problem and be able to formulate a plan to optimize therapy

title: Hospital Pharmacy Experience in Mainland China
description: This course is an elective clerkship which introduces hospital pharmacy practice and clinical pharmacy services in various research and teaching hospitals in mainland China. Specialties involved in the training include cardiology, general internal medicine, and critical care medicine. Students will also be exposed to information regarding licensure requirements and employment opportunities in mainland China.

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Geriatrics
description: This elective clerkship is designed to provide training experience to students in geriatric pharmacy practice and patient care within the health system. The clerkship learning strategies include ward round, pharmacy round, in-service staff education, patient counselling, and interaction with different health-care professionals in geriatric medicine. Students will have the opportunity to assess medication regimen for drug-related problems in geriatric illnesses, provide drug information to patients, caregivers and medical staff in geriatric care, and recognize the role of pharmacist in multidisciplinary team in geriatrics.

description: This course is an elective clerkship which introduces the concept of utilizing pharmacogenomics (PG) information and integrating it in clinical decision making. title: Drug Information Clerkship
description: The Drug Information Clerkship is a clinical clerkship rotation designed to provide students with practical training to further develop drug information skills. Drug information involves not only the literature evaluation of evidence based information but also drug education and identification of adverse drug events to ensure patient safety. Building upon the knowledge of the different references, students will learn techniques that will enhance their proficiency in information search and critical assessment skills. Verbal and written communication skills are crucial in drug information in order for such information to be disseminated effectively. To emphasize these areas, students are expected to communicate with patients through drug counseling, with the public by conducting educational programs, and with other health care professionals and colleagues during therapeutic use evaluation. Utilizing the School of Pharmacy’s On-Line Drug-Enquiry Platform (AMPOULE), the clerkship exposes students to the many different types of questions from real patients who expect high quality and professional advice.

title: Graduation Project II
requirements: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy; Prerequisite: PHAR5824
description: This course consists of independent and teamwork with supervision. Students are required to implement a predetermined practice-based project of interest in their work settings. Students are expected to be involved in project implementation, outcome measurement, result analysis, report writing and presentation. Pre-requisite: PHAR5824.
outcome: Upon completion of the project, students should be able to • Implement a practice-based project that can demonstrate pharmacist’s impact on patient care, teaching, pharmaceutical research and development or administrative management • Demonstrate application of knowledge and motivation to learn • Identify potential obstacles in conducting a project and formulate strategies to solve them accordingly • Non-verbally and verbally communicate effectively as demonstrated by written reports and oral presentation of project • Be flexible and adaptive to unforeseen circumstances and strive to take alternative approaches in different situations • Demonstrate ability in working as a team and good interpersonal skills • Demonstrate good time-management skills and logical organization of tasks • Develop working knowledge on computer software commonly used for data analysis
